programme.title: Party Political Broadcast
programme.desc: By the Alliance Party.

programme.title: Comic Relief 2015
programme.desc: Red Nose Day returns with an evening of entertainment to raise money for disadvantaged people in the UK and Africa, and this year the fun comes live from the London Palladium. 7pm Lenny Henry and Davina McCall kick off the first hour of laughs, which includes Rowan Atkinson in a new Mr Bean sketch, guest starring Ben Miller and Rebecca Front. Tess Daly and Claudia Winkleman pop in to announce the winner of The People's Strictly, after their performances on Wednesday night, and Dermot O'Leary finally gets the chance to sit down as his 24-hour dance marathon comes to an end. 8pm David Walliams joins Davina as co-host, and introduces a special Vicar of Dibley in which Geraldine (Dawn French) is up for the job of bishop - only to find she has some very famous competition. There's also music by Ella Henderson, highlights of Peter Kay's Phoenix Nights Live and an appearance by Mr Khan. 9pm Davina and John Bishop present a brand new Little Britain sketch featuring David Walliams as Lou and his new friend Professor Stephen Hawking. There's also a live sketch in which Eddie Izzard teams up with the hosts and a song from Sam Smith. Continues at 10.40pm. Times and details may vary.

programme.title: Comic Relief 2015
programme.desc: Continued coverage of the charity event from the stage of the London Palladium, as famous faces aim to raise a few laughs in their bid to make money for disadvantaged people across the UK and Africa. Those taking the stage include Claudia Winkleman and Sarah Millican, and there are sketches featuring Stephen Fry, Miranda Hart, Sheridan Smith and several other national treasures. 11.30pm-1am Things get a little more adult-oriented as the show heads into the night, with the likes of Russell Brand, Doc Brown, Trevor Noah and a live sketch from Cardinal Burns taking the fundraiser through to its conclusion.

programme.title: Comic Relief 2015
programme.sub-title: Comic Relief - Making It Funny for Money
programme.desc: After an evening of big laughs aimed at raising some even bigger money, Greg James goes behind the scenes to find out how the night's TV highlights came together. Including David Walliams sharing his experience of filming with Professor Stephen Hawking in a Little Britain special, and Ben Miller talking about co-starring in a new Mr Bean sketch. Plus, an interview with Stephen Fry.

programme.title: BBC News
programme.desc: The latest national and international stories as they break.

programme.title: Breakfast
programme.desc: A round-up of national and international news, plus sports reports, weather forecasts and arts and entertainment features. Including NewsWatch at 7.45.

programme.title: Saturday Kitchen Live
programme.desc: James Martin is joined by chefs Paul Rankin and Virgilio Martinez, and actress Sally Lindsay faces her food heaven or hell. Plus, wine expert Peter Richards reveals his choice of drinks to complement the dishes created in the studio, and there are archive clips of programmes featuring Rick Stein, Tom Kerridge, The Incredible Spice Men, Gennaro Contaldo and Antonio Carluccio.

programme.title: Mary Berry Cooks
programme.desc: The food writer and Great British Bake Off judge demonstrates how to cater for a large gathering of guests at a special occasion. She prepares dishes for a buffet supper, including beef and mushroom stew with mustard mash, salmon en croute with salad, chocolate and orange panna cotta and a meringue tranche with berries and cream.

programme.title: Football Focus
programme.desc: Dan Walker and guests look ahead to the weekend's Premier League fixtures, including Burnley v Manchester City at Turf Moor, Chelsea v Southampton at Stamford Bridge and Tottenham Hotspur v Manchester United at White Hart Lane. Plus, reports on the lunchtime London derby between Crystal Palace and Queens Park Rangers.

programme.title: Formula 1
programme.sub-title: The Australian Grand Prix - Qualifying Highlights
programme.desc: Suzi Perry presents action from the battle for pole position in the opening round of the season at Albert Park in Melbourne. Mercedes' Lewis Hamilton claimed pole position here last year, but failed to complete two laps of the race, with his team-mate Nico Rosberg taking the honours. With commentary by Ben Edwards and David Coulthard.

programme.title: Live Six Nations Rugby Union
programme.desc: Wales v Ireland (Kick-off 2.30pm). Gabby Logan presents coverage of the opening match in the fourth and penultimate round of fixtures, which takes place at Millennium Stadium. Wales lost their only previous home game in this year's championship, falling to a 21-16 defeat to England despite leading 16-8 at half-time. Warren Gatland's men will be eager to repay their passionate home crowd following that collapse, and having been subjected to a 26-3 loss to Ireland at Aviva Stadium last season, they may feel as though they have a score to settle. With commentary by Eddie Butler, Jonathan Davies and Phillip Matthews, and analysis from Keith Wood, Shane Williams and Martyn Williams.

programme.title: Live Six Nations Rugby Union
programme.desc: England v Scotland (Kick-off 5.00pm). John Inverdale presents coverage of the match from Twickenham, which also sees the teams contest the Calcutta Cup, a trophy that was first competed for in 1879. The hosts will enter this fixture as the favourites for victory owing to their superior recent record in this fixture, having not lost to Scotland since 2008, and last having a home defeat inflicted on them in 1983. However, Vern Cotter's men have shown signs of improvement during this campaign, displaying plenty of gumption in narrow defeats away to France and at home to Wales, and they will be keen to claim a morale-boosting win. With commentary by Andrew Cotter and Brian Moore, analysis from Jeremy Guscott, Clive Woodward and Andy Nicol, and reports by Jill Douglas.

programme.title: BBC News; Regional News and Weather
The Voice UK
programme.desc: Emma Willis and Marvin Humes present the first of two knockout rounds this weekend, in which Rita Ora and Will.i.am reduce their teams down to the three acts that will perform in the live shows. The vocalists each choose a solo song and step into the spotlight for what could be the final time, knowing that five out of each group will be leaving disappointed at the end of the day. Continues tomorrow.

programme.title: The National Lottery: Win Your Wish List
programme.desc: Shane Richie hosts the game show in which two contestants pick a selection of dream prizes to make up their personal wish lists, all of which have a connection to their shared history together. They then face categories of questions in an attempt to win their chosen items. Plus, the Lotto and Thunderball draws, presented by Gaby Roslin. Last in the series.

programme.title: Casualty
programme.desc: Lily is involved in an accident on her way home from work when her moped collides with a schoolgirl - and when she admits she was tired, the youngster's father is furious. Has the young doctor jeopardised her career? The medics grow suspicious of a couple when urine tests on a mother and her baby bring up traces of amphetamines. Connie and Rita argue as the team continues to be overworked, while Cal steals money from Ethan for Taylor's charity.

programme.title: Match of the Day
programme.desc: Gary Lineker presents action from the latest Premier League fixtures, including Burnley v Manchester City at Turf Moor and Arsenal v West Ham United at the Emirates Stadium. Despite being at opposite ends of the table, the reigning champions could take nothing for granted against Burnley given their recent excellent point away to Chelsea. Meanwhile, Arsenal were looking for their ninth consecutive league win over the Hammers. Plus, Crystal Palace v Queens Park Rangers, Leicester City v Hull City, Sunderland v Aston Villa and West Bromwich Albion v Stoke City.

programme.title: The Football League Show
programme.desc: Manish Bhasin presents highlights and all the goals from the latest fixtures in the Championship, League One and League Two, including Norwich City v Derby County at Carrow Road, Middlesbrough v Ipswich Town at the Riverside Stadium, and Rotherham United v Wigan Athletic at the New York Stadium.

programme.title: EastEnders
programme.desc: The highs and lows of life with the residents of Albert Square, Walford.

programme.title: Breakfast
programme.desc: A round-up of national and international news, plus sports reports, weather forecasts and arts and entertainment features.

programme.title: Match of the Day
programme.desc: Gary Lineker presents action from the latest Premier League fixtures, including Burnley v Manchester City at Turf Moor and Arsenal v West Ham United at the Emirates Stadium. Despite being at opposite ends of the table, the reigning champions could take nothing for granted against Burnley given their recent excellent point away to Chelsea. Meanwhile, Arsenal were looking for their ninth consecutive league win over the Hammers. Plus, Crystal Palace v Queens Park Rangers, Leicester City v Hull City, Sunderland v Aston Villa and West Bromwich Albion v Stoke City.

programme.title: The Andrew Marr Show
programme.desc: Chancellor of the Exchequer George Osborne joins the presenter ahead of the final Budget before the General Election. Plus, Shadow Chancellor Ed Balls and actor Sean Penn also stop by to discuss topical politics, current affairs and the arts. Including news and weather at 9.00.

programme.title: The Big Questions
programme.desc: Nicky Campbell presents moral and religious discussions on topical issues, live from Leicester, with contributions by members of the studio audience.

programme.title: Sunday Politics
programme.desc: The week's events at Westminster, presented by Andrew Neil. Including coverage from around the Province with Mark Carruthers.

programme.title: MOTD2 Extra
programme.desc: Mark Chapman presents football discussion with the Match of the Day team, focusing on the headlines from yesterday's matches and news ahead of today's fixtures.

programme.title: Formula 1
programme.desc: Suzi Perry presents action from the opening race of the season, held at Albert Park in Melbourne, where Mercedes' Lewis Hamilton began his defence of the title. The champion will have been looking to avoid a repeat of this race last year when he withdrew on the second lap due to engine trouble. However, he was expected to face stiff competition from his team-mate and last year's winner here Nico Rosberg, with Sebastian Vettel also looking to make an impact on his debut for Ferrari. With commentary by Ben Edwards and David Coulthard.

programme.title: Live Six Nations Rugby Union
programme.desc: Italy v France (Kick-off 3.00pm). John Inverdale presents coverage of the match from Stadio Olimpico in Rome, where the fourth and penultimate round of fixtures concludes. While the French would normally be considered as favourites for any contest between these two nations, their last two visits to Italy in the Six Nations have yielded no points, after the Italians stunned them with a 22-21 victory in 2011, and then triumphed 23-18 in 2013. With commentary by Eddie Butler and Andy Nicol, analysis from Carlo Del Fava, Keith Wood and Jeremy Guscott, and reports by Sonja McLaughlan.

programme.title: Songs of Praise
programme.desc: Diane Louise Jordan marks Mothering Sunday by meeting a woman who chose to adopt rather than have her own children. Plus, Eamon Martin, the Archbishop of Armagh and spiritual leader of Catholics in Ireland, stops by for a chat in the run-up to St Patrick's Day, and there is a performance of Danny Boy by Celtic Woman.

programme.title: BBC News; Regional News and Weather
The Big Painting Challenge
programme.desc: Una Stubbs and Richard Bacon present the art competition from Tate Britain on the banks of the Thames, where the remaining amateurs focus on the human form for their next three challenges. As they arrive, they are greeted by two semi-naked men, setting the tone for the first task in which they make anatomically correct life drawings. This is followed by the seemingly impossible task of sketching a rhythmic gymnast and her flickering ribbon, followed by the final challenge - a flamenco dance captured in chalk and pastel.

programme.title: Countryfile
programme.desc: The show comes from Northern Ireland, where Matt Baker finds out about the hares that have made their home at Belfast International Airport and helps out at RSPB reserve Portmore Lough, the first in the country to offer a year-long residential volunteer programme. Helen Skelton takes to the waters at Ardglass Harbour, where entire communities have come together to share their boat-building skills, and explores the beauty of Strangford Lough. Adam Henson sees how farming has shaped the limestone landscape of North Yorkshire and Tom Heap reports on how British National Parks are being affected by budget cuts. Including Weather for the Week Ahead.

programme.title: The Voice UK
programme.desc: The knockout rounds come to an end and the line-up for the live shows is revealed as coaches Tom Jones and Ricky Wilson finally settle on the three acts they are each taking through to the quarter-finals. Presented by Emma Willis and Marvin Humes.

programme.title: Poldark
programme.desc: Period drama set in late 18th-century Cornwall, based on the novels by Winston Graham. The closure of the local tin mine leaves hundreds out of work and desperately poor, so Ross considers reopening his family mine with a view to bringing prosperity back to the area. He takes time out to accompany his cousin Verity to a ball, where she falls in love with Captain Blamey - a man who turns out to be hiding a dark secret - and Ross causes a stir by getting intimate with the now-married Elizabeth.

programme.title: BBC News; Regional News and Weather
Match of the Day 2
programme.desc: Mark Chapman reviews the day's Premier League action, featuring Manchester United v Tottenham Hotspur at Old Trafford, Chelsea v Southampton at Stamford Bridge and Everton v Newcastle United at Goodison Park. United and Spurs shared the spoils in December's reverse fixture, while the Blues and Southampton also could not be separated when they met at Saint Mary's Stadium, and Newcastle are looking to complete a double over the Toffees.

programme.title: Comic Relief 2015
programme.desc: A selection of clips from Friday's entertainment extravaganza from London Palladium, where celebrities including Lenny Henry and John Bishop performed to raise money for disadvantaged people in the UK and Africa. Highlights include a special edition of Little Britain featuring David Walliams, Catherine Tate and Stephen Hawking.

programme.title: The Apprentice USA
programme.desc: Past winners of the series Piers Morgan, Joan Rivers and Bret Michaels return to conduct individual interviews, and to advise Donald Trump on who should be chosen as the final two contestants. The pair who are lucky enough to progress will each be assisted by three previously fired candidates and must produce a launch campaign for 7Up Retro. They also design a new can, produce a 30-second commercial, create an editorial and present the entire campaign at a gala.

programme.title: Breakfast
programme.desc: Round-up of national and international news, plus the latest from the money markets.

programme.title: Heir Hunters
programme.desc: A simple case becomes complicated when family secrets are uncovered, while another reveals a great-grandfather's life on the docks in the early days of diving. An uncle's part in the defeat of Nazi Germany in the Second World War is also highlighted. Plus, details of unclaimed estates where heirs still need to be traced.

programme.title: Homes Under the Hammer
programme.desc: Developers Lucy Alexander and Martin Roberts explore an old prefabricated property in the New Forest and a home in Derby, before speaking to the owners to find out what they paid for them at auction and their plans for the future.

programme.title: The Sheriffs Are Coming
programme.desc: Return of the programme following the work of High Court enforcement officers. In the first edition, Tommy and Craig confront a garage owner who denies he is responsible for a faulty car sale to a recently married couple, while a credit card customer claims the company owes more than £35,000. Plus, a home rental goes badly wrong, and the sheriffs try to make the letting agent pay what is due.

programme.title: Watchdog Test House
programme.desc: Sophie Raworth, Tony Livesey and Michelle Ackerley look at how to select a trustworthy garage to fix cars, and whether paying more for a battery guarantees whether it will last longer.

programme.title: Bargain Hunt
programme.desc: The teams head to the Westpoint Arena in Exeter, with experts Kate Bliss and Colin Young on hand to help two sets of mother and daughters battle it out to make the most profit at auction. Presented by Charlie Ross.

programme.title: Doctors
programme.desc: Ayesha's morals are tested when an old friend comes back into her life asking for help, while Heather questions Jimmi about what she learned at the dinner party. Elsewhere, Barry tries to act the hero and save the Mill. Medical drama, starring Laura Rollins and Adrian Lewis Morgan.

programme.title: The Edge
programme.desc: Quiz, hosted by Mark Benton, in which four contestants answer questions for the right to roll balls along cash lanes. Round by round they try to usurp their competitors in the tactical stakes of runway selection, and the nearer their balls gets to The Edge the more money they bank. However if they go over, they face elimination.

programme.title: Escape to the Country
programme.desc: Alistair Appleton helps a couple with a generous budget of £700,000 to find their ideal property in Shropshire, but their dream home must also have enough space to accommodate a chocolate business. While in the county, Alistair visits a historic film set.

programme.title: Holiday of My Lifetime with Len Goodman
programme.desc: Strictly Come Dancing judge Len Goodman invites celebrity guests to reminisce about one of their favourite holidays. TV cook and Hairy Biker Dave Myers accompanies the host on a revisit to the Isle of Man to recall a 1967 seaside vacation where he reveals how his original trip played a significant role in his love of food and motorbikes.

programme.title: Flog It!
programme.desc: The programme heads to Wellington College, Berkshire, which Paul Martin discovers was built as a tribute to a famous British general. Elizabeth Talbot finds a collection of 17 Beatrix Potter animals among the antiques brought for evaluation, while Philip Serrell admires a silver tea set.

programme.title: Pointless
programme.desc: Quiz show in which pairs of contestants try to score the fewest points possible by giving the least obvious correct answers to questions posed to 100 people before the show. At the end of each round, the team with the most points is eliminated until the final two pairs battle for the chance to compete for a cash prize. Presented by Alexander Armstrong and Richard Osman.

programme.title: BBC Newsline
programme.desc: The latest news and views from around the Province.

programme.title: The One Show
programme.desc: The first visit of the week to the One Show studio, where Matt Baker and Alex Jones present the usual mix of topical stories and celebrity chat.

programme.title: Great Irish Journeys with Martha Kearney
programme.desc: The broadcaster follows in the footsteps of 19th-century artist George Victor Du Noyer, who spent 35 years charting the landscape, people and buildings of Ireland. In the first episode, Martha gives an introduction to Du Noyer's work, and travels to the Bog of Allen, which lies between the Liffey and Shannon, and the Old Head of Kinsale in Co Cork.

programme.title: EastEnders
programme.desc: The highs and lows of life with the residents of Albert Square, Walford.

programme.title: Panorama
programme.sub-title: What Britain Wants: Somewhere to Work
programme.desc: As the General Election approaches, Clive Myrie focuses on the modern workplace in the third of four editions investigating whether Britain today is up to the task of delivering on the things that have traditionally defined `good living'.

programme.title: The Irish Rock Story: A Tale of Two Cities
programme.desc: Documentary telling the story of how rock music helped bring about change for Ireland over 40 years, and how the sounds that emerged were grounded in the musical traditions of Ireland's two main cities. From the pioneering touring showbands of the late 1950s through to the modern day, the film examines how the harder sounds of Belfast merged with the more folk-centric traditions of Dublin, celebrates some of the key musicians to have emerged from the Irish scene, and reveals how they were influenced by the political, social and cultural climate of their surroundings. With contributions from U2, Sinead O'Connor and Bob Geldof.

programme.title: New Tricks
programme.desc: Jack announces he is quitting the team, but before Sandra, Brian and Gerry can question his reasons, shadowy Whitehall figure Stephen Fisher arrives with one of his secret cases - the unsolved murder of a woman dating back more than 160 years. But with just 24 hours to solve it, will the sleuths find time to get to the bottom of Jack's shock decision and persuade him to stick around?

programme.title: Live at the Apollo
programme.desc: Sarah Millican hosts an evening of stand-up at the Apollo in Hammersmith, London, treating the audience to her own brand of humour, before introducing routines by camp comic Joe Lycett and award-winning funnyman Russell Kane.

programme.title: Junkhearts
programme.desc: A traumatised, alcoholic former soldier offers a homeless teenager a place to stay, and begins to pull himself together as he plays the role of surrogate father. However, his kindness is exploited by her manipulative boyfriend, who turns his house into a drug den. Drama, with Eddie Marsan, Candese Reid, Tom Sturridge and Romola Garai.

programme.title: BBC News
programme.desc: The latest national and international stories as they break.

programme.title: Breakfast
programme.desc: Round-up of national and international news, plus the latest from the money markets.

programme.title: Heir Hunters
programme.desc: Research into two family trees uncovers how Britain's post-war building boom boosted Irish immigration, and how the British infantry fought their way across the border into Nazi Germany. Plus, details of unclaimed estates where heirs are still being sought.

programme.title: Homes Under the Hammer
programme.desc: Developers Lucy Alexander and Martin Roberts explore properties about to be auctioned, then follow the sale and talk to the buyers about their plans for the buildings. This episode features a derelict house in Surrey where the new owners plan to build four houses, a novice developer in Crewe, and a couple of seasoned property professionals in Cheshire.

programme.title: The Sheriffs Are Coming
programme.desc: The officers are called in to reclaim a London pub from squatters, but one of the men inside is not in the mood to move out. Elsewhere, a man gets help reclaiming money from a company that did not pay him after selling his motorhome, and a doctor in Kent goes in search of wages she has not yet been paid despite several months of work.

programme.title: Watchdog Test House
programme.desc: Presenters Sophie Raworth, Michelle Ackerley and Tony Livesey find out how modern wheelchairs are made safe, and reveal which part of the house contains the most germs.

programme.title: Bargain Hunt
programme.desc: Experts David Harper and Kate Bliss take two teams to the Lincolnshire Showground in search of valuable items, while presenter Tim Wonnacott visits Lotherton Hall, a country house in Leeds.

programme.title: Doctors
programme.desc: Niamh witnesses a patient falling from a great height and dying, and Rob has to dig deep to uncover the truth about what happened. Medical drama series set in a busy Midlands surgery, starring Jessica Regan and Chris Walker.

programme.title: The Edge
programme.desc: Quiz, hosted by Mark Benton, in which four contestants answer questions for the right to roll balls along cash lanes. Round by round they try to usurp their competitors in the tactical stakes of runway selection, and the nearer their balls gets to The Edge the more money they bank. However if they go over, they face elimination.

programme.title: Escape to the Country
programme.desc: Jules Hudson helps a couple from London with a generous £1,000,000 budget search for a property in rural Somerset. Away from the house hunt, the presenter visits Weston-super-Mare, where he views a display of sand sculptures.

programme.title: Holiday of My Lifetime with Len Goodman
programme.desc: The host accompanies Esther Rantzen to the Isle of Wight to relive a holiday she had when she was six years old in 1946. They visit the village of Bembridge for a spot of crabbing, head to Carisbrooke Castle, and enjoy a chairlift ride with views of the coast.

programme.title: Flog It!
programme.desc: Kate Bateman and David Barby head for Essex to attend a valuing day at Colchester Town Hall, where they find a pair of valuable paintings of fish and two Clarice Cliff items. Meanwhile, Paul Martin visits a nearby stately home being restored to its former glory by a group of local campaigners.

programme.title: Pointless
programme.desc: Quiz show in which pairs of contestants try to score the fewest points possible by giving the least obvious correct answers to questions posed to 100 people before the show. At the end of each round, the team with the most points is eliminated until the final two pairs battle for the chance to compete for a cash prize. Presented by Alexander Armstrong and Richard Osman.

programme.title: BBC Newsline
programme.desc: The latest news and views from around the Province.

programme.title: The One Show
programme.desc: Another mix of nationwide reports and live studio-based chat, hosted by Matt Baker and Alex Jones.

programme.title: EastEnders
programme.desc: The highs and lows of life with the residents of Albert Square, Walford.

programme.title: Holby City
programme.desc: Jonny is behind bars, where he meets his frightened young cellmate, who has been targeted by a fellow prisoner - and when an attack takes place, the nurse puts his life on the line by intervening in the scuffle. As Raf brings in a facial reconstruction expert for Harry, the patient wallows in self-pity and refuses any further treatment - until a young lady gives him something to think about. Zosia is candid about her bipolar with a patient, only to realise that honesty isn't always the best policy.

programme.title: Ordinary Lies
programme.desc: Ensemble drama following the workers at a car showroom, revealing what happens when moments of desperation lead some of them into telling big lies - spur-of-the-moment deceptions that quickly spiral out of control. The first episode focuses on salesman Marty, played by Jason Manford, who is on his final warning for being late - so when he sleeps through his alarm after a heavy night of drinking, he panics and comes up with a drastic excuse. His colleagues are all sympathetic - but now he has to live with the lie that his wife is dead. Max Beesley, Jo Joyner, Mackenzie Crook and Michelle Keegan co-star.

programme.title: Spotlight
programme.desc: Mandy McAuley takes to the streets to reveal the secret lives of homeless people.

programme.title: Life After Suicide
programme.desc: The leading cause of death in men below 50 is suicide, yet people still seem reluctant to talk about it. Birkenhead woman Angela Samata, whose partner Mark took his own life 11 years ago, meets others who have suffered a similar loss, asking why some people choose to take their own lives and whether those left behind can ever come to terms with their bereavement. Those she meets include Downton Abbey actor David Robb, talking about the death of his actress wife Briony McRoberts in 2013, a Somerset farmer and his five young daughters, and a Norfolk woman who is living with the suicides of both her husband and son.

programme.title: The Double
programme.desc: A retired CIA agent returns to duty when a senator is murdered. The former spy believes the killing has all the hallmarks of an infamous Soviet assassin he spent most of his career in pursuit of, and joins forces with the inexperienced FBI agent assigned to the case. Espionage thriller, starring Richard Gere, Topher Grace and Martin Sheen.

programme.title: BBC News
programme.desc: The latest national and international stories as they break.

programme.title: Breakfast
programme.desc: Round-up of national and international news, plus the latest from the money markets.

programme.title: Heir Hunters
programme.desc: Research into family trees uncovers the history of domestic service in one of the world's most prestigious universities and how luxury transatlantic steamliners helped change the course of history. Plus, details of unclaimed estates with heirs still needing to be found.

programme.title: Homes Under the Hammer
programme.desc: Developers Lucy Alexander and Martin Roberts explore a cottage in Cornwall, a property in Cumbria and a home in Northern Ireland. They then find out what they were sold for at auction and speak to the new owners about their plans.

programme.title: The Sheriffs Are Coming
programme.desc: Squatters return to a London pub, and police are called when one man reacts violently during the eviction. Sheriff Chris has a confrontation with a used-car dealer, and Lawrence and Kev have an unusual enforcement at a vintage clothing store. Narrated by David Reed.

programme.title: Watchdog Test House
programme.desc: Investigating the dangers of using counterfeit electrical goods, and examining how people can find out whether an appliance has been part of a safety recall. Presented by Sophie Raworth, Michelle Ackerley and Tony Livesey.

programme.title: Bargain Hunt
programme.desc: Tim Wonnacott travels to the Staffordshire Showground, where experts Christina Trevanion and Thomas Plant assist two more teams looking to pick up bargains to hopefully sell on for a profit.

programme.title: Doctors
programme.desc: Al tries to limit the damage when a visiting academic is diagnosed with suspected diphtheria. Meanwhile, Heather finds it hard to choose between a girls' night in and a trip to the cinema with Jimmi.

programme.title: The Edge
programme.desc: Quiz, hosted by Mark Benton, in which four contestants answer questions for the right to roll balls along cash lanes. Round by round they try to usurp their competitors in the tactical stakes of runway selection, and the nearer their balls gets to The Edge the more money they bank. However if they go over, they face elimination.

programme.title: Escape to the Country
programme.desc: Jonnie Irwin helps a couple with a budget of £400,000 move nearer to their daughter in rural Herefordshire. While in the county, the presenter also meets dairy farmers who use innovative methods in their work.

programme.title: Holiday of My Lifetime with Len Goodman
programme.desc: Presenter Chris Hollins reminisces about a 1988 holiday in Oxford he took as part of a cricket tour, being driven back to the location in a classic Mini by the Strictly Come Dancing judge. He is taken to the university halls he stayed in as a 17-year-old, and Len invites some of Chris's friends from the 1980s holiday to take part in a game from back in the day called Spoof.

programme.title: Flog It!
programme.desc: Rolling Stones autographs cause excitement at an antiques fair in Winchester, Hampshire, and expert Christina Trevanion develops a fondness for an old teddy bear. James Lewis finds ceramic sheep slightly disturbing, and presenter Paul Martin visits Chawton House to explore the link between author Jane Austen and an American millionaire.

programme.title: Pointless
programme.desc: Quiz show in which pairs of contestants try to score the fewest points possible by giving the least obvious correct answers to questions posed to 100 people before the show. At the end of each round, the team with the most points is eliminated until the final two pairs battle for the chance to compete for a cash prize. Presented by Alexander Armstrong and Richard Osman.

programme.title: BBC Newsline
programme.desc: The latest news and views from around the Province.

programme.title: The One Show
programme.desc: Matt Baker and Alex Jones host the live magazine show, with a team of roving reporters presenting stories of interest from around the UK, plus big-name studio guests.

programme.title: MasterChef
programme.desc: John Torode and Gregg Wallace put more keen cooks to the test in the second heat. As usual they begin by serving up their Calling Card, a dish that showcases their talents. The judges' two favourites then sit it out while the others reinvent what they've just made, creating a new plate of food based on the main ingredient from the first round. After this cook-off, one of the amateurs is sent home, before the remaining four prepare dinner for a trio of former MasterChef champions, after which Friday's first two quarter-finalists will be decided.

programme.title: The Billion Dollar Chicken Shop
programme.desc: Documentary providing an insight into the daily operations of staff at KFC, from those making the decisions in the boardroom to those in the kitchens of some of the 850 restaurants around the country. They include 17-year-old Beth, who has just started work in Manchester but is struggling to find her way, and company `policeman' Brian, who carries out spot-checks to scrutinise cleanliness and food standards. Cameras also visit one of the farms that supplies the company with the 23 million chickens it serves each year, and in Middleton, near Manchester, angry residents try to prevent a new KFC opening on their doorstep.

programme.title: Nolan Live
programme.desc: Stephen Nolan probes the issues that matter, focusing on the stories of the week and the people making the headlines in lively debates with the studio audience and guest panellists.

programme.title: A Question of Sport
programme.desc: Scotland international Duncan Weir, rugby union referee Nigel Owens, pundit Jonathan Davies and TV presenter and rugby enthusiast Nick Knowles join team captains Phil Tufnell and Matt Dawson for a special edition of the quiz. Presented by Sue Barker.

programme.title: Hollywood Homicide
programme.desc: Two cops are put to the test by the baffling case of a rapper murdered on stage, but they are more concerned with escaping the daily grind of catching crooks than the machinations of the music industry. While one moonlights unsuccessfully as an estate agent, the other sees this high-profile case as a chance to fulfil his dream of becoming an actor. Action comedy, starring Harrison Ford, Josh Hartnett and Lena Olin.

programme.title: BBC News
programme.desc: The latest national and international stories as they break.

programme.title: Breakfast
programme.desc: Round-up of national and international news, plus the latest from the money markets.

programme.title: Heir Hunters
programme.desc: The probate detectives try to find the relatives of a south London woman, but they are misled by a trail of dubious clues and are left questioning their knowledge. Meanwhile, research into family trees reveals the lives of British soldiers in 19th-century India.

programme.title: Homes Under the Hammer
programme.desc: Lucy Alexander and Martin Roberts explore a bungalow, a terraced house and a unique water tower about to be auctioned in Gosforth in Newcastle, Maidstone in Kent and Northern Ireland's Newtownards. They speak to the new owners after the sales, then revisit the homes to see how the developers have progressed.

programme.title: The Sheriffs Are Coming
programme.desc: Tommy helps the owner of a Mini who took his car to a garage for an engine refit, and received a nasty surprise when he returned to pick it up. Lawrence and Kev search for the people who owe a businesswoman money, and have left her on the verge of making redundancies, while Mark and Tony get locked in a used-car garage.

programme.title: Watchdog Test House
programme.desc: Sophie Raworth and the team investigate how much car safety has developed over the years. Plus, how people can protect their families from the dangerous food bacteria campylobacter.

programme.title: Bargain Hunt
programme.desc: Antiques experts Charlie Ross and Catherine Southon help two teams in Dorking, Surrey, search for valuable items to take to auction. Meanwhile, presenter Tim Wonnacott locates a rather special pen-and-ink watercolour painting.

programme.title: Doctors
programme.desc: A vehicle is stolen from a car showroom, and Rob finds himself on the trail of a daring and elusive thief. Meanwhile, Jimmi and Heather go bowling, Mrs Tembe puts Barry though his paces and Niamh makes a confession to Emma. Starring Chris Walker.

programme.title: The Edge
programme.desc: Quiz, hosted by Mark Benton, in which four contestants answer questions for the right to roll balls along cash lanes. Round by round they try to usurp their competitors in the tactical stakes of runway selection, and the nearer their balls gets to The Edge the more money they bank. However if they go over, they face elimination.

programme.title: Escape to the Country
programme.desc: Jonnie Irwin helps a couple search for a home in rural Somerset on a budget of £600,000. They want to move away from their urban London life and hope to find a property with holiday business potential. Jonnie also visits the world's largest balloon factory.

programme.title: Holiday of My Lifetime with Len Goodman
programme.desc: The Strictly Come Dancing judge accompanies Ainsley Harriott to Blackpool, Lancashire, where the chef reminisces about his holiday there in 1974. They enjoy the fairground, taking a ride on the Big Dipper rollercoaster, and go to the Winter Gardens where Ainsley saw his father perform on stage for the first time.

programme.title: Flog It!
programme.desc: Paul Martin is joined by Philip Serrill and Charlie Ross to cast their expert eye over items brought in to Peterborough Cathedral by the public, including a Georgian chair and a Cantonese fan. Plus, Paul heads out in to the countryside to shed light on a forgotten 18th-century literary talent, Northamptonshire's Peasant Poet.

programme.title: Pointless
programme.desc: Quiz show in which pairs of contestants try to score the fewest points possible by giving the least obvious correct answers to questions posed to 100 people before the show. At the end of each round, the team with the most points is eliminated until the final two pairs battle for the chance to compete for a cash prize. Presented by Alexander Armstrong and Richard Osman.

programme.title: BBC Newsline
programme.desc: The latest news and views from around the Province.

programme.title: The One Show
programme.desc: Matt Baker and Alex Jones present the live magazine show featuring a mixture of celebrity chat and stories of interest.

programme.title: EastEnders
programme.desc: The highs and lows of life with the residents of Albert Square, Walford.

programme.title: MasterChef
programme.desc: Five more cooks compete for a place in the quarter-final, preparing a dish that represents who they are, before the three least successful hopefuls rustle up a different plate of food using the same main ingredient in the Reinvention Test. One cook is shown the door, and then the remaining four face the daunting task of preparing dinner for a trio of MasterChef finalists and runners-up. But which pair will John Torode and Gregg Wallace put through?

programme.title: The Truth About
programme.desc: In the first of four documentaries focusing on health matters, Fiona Phillips investigates what sugar does to the body, finds out why some people have more of a sweet tooth than others and how sugar is added to many supermarket favourites believed to be purely savoury. She is also joined by four volunteers whose sugar-heavy diets could be putting their health at risk. Together they come up with ways to beat their sweet cravings and reduce their intake - but will it make a noticeable difference?

programme.title: The View
programme.desc: Mark Carruthers presents a review of the week's political news, including reports on the latest events at Stormont and Westminster. Plus, comment and analysis with studio guests.

programme.title: Question Time
programme.desc: David Dimbleby chairs a debate from Croydon, south London, as a panel of guests faces topical questions from the audience.

programme.title: This Week
programme.desc: Andrew Neil presents round-table chat, in which he and his guests take a light-hearted romp through the political and parliamentary developments of the past seven days. They'll be discussing who is making the headlines and the issues that matter to both MPs and the public.

programme.title: BBC News
programme.desc: The latest national and international stories as they break.

programme.title: Breakfast
programme.desc: Round-up of national and international news, plus the latest from the money markets.

programme.title: Stargazing Live
programme.desc: Professor Brian Cox and Dara O Briain return to Jodrell Bank Observatory to host live coverage of the total solar eclipse. Liz Bonnin beams pictures from a specially equipped plane high above the clouds, while Chris Hollins joins the crowds on the Faroe Islands to witness the spectacle from the ground. Solar scientist Dr Lucie Green assists Newsround's Leah Boleto and hundreds of children in carrying out a nationwide weather experiment, and Carol Kirkwood reveals where in the country people can get the best views.

programme.title: Homes Under the Hammer
programme.desc: Developers Lucy Alexander and Martin Roberts explore a large semi-detached home in Derbyshire, a four-bedroom terraced house in Belfast, and a modest one-bedroom flat in Clydebank, West Dunbartonshire. They then discover what they were sold for at auction and speak to the new owners about their plans.

programme.title: The Sheriffs Are Coming
programme.desc: The High Court enforcement officers are needed to get squatters out of a London pub, but heavy barricades block their way. Meanwhile, Craig is at the garage trying to get one Birmingham motorist's money back after she winds up in court, and sheriff Tommy is down on the farm, where he meets an unexpectedly helpful debtor. Last in the series.

programme.title: Watchdog Test House
programme.desc: In the run-up to Easter, the team investigates how much money needs to be spent on good quality chocolate. Last in the series.

programme.title: Bargain Hunt
programme.desc: Tim Wonnacott and experts Catherine Southon and Anita Manning travel to Brackley in Northamptonshire for the buying and selling contest. In an area steeped in motor-racing tradition, the two teams of loving couples compete to make the most cash.

programme.title: Doctors
programme.desc: Heston tries to get to the bottom of a patient's heart trouble and determine whether the problem is linked to stress or something more sinister. Meanwhile, Zara struggles with childcare, Al is up to something suspicious, and Jimmi prepares to surprise Heather.

programme.title: The Edge
programme.desc: Quiz, hosted by Mark Benton, in which four contestants answer questions for the right to roll balls along cash lanes. Round by round they try to usurp their competitors in the tactical stakes of runway selection, and the nearer their balls gets to The Edge the more money they bank. However if they go over, they face elimination.

programme.title: Escape to the Country
programme.desc: Jules Hudson helps a husband and wife with a budget of £375,000 look for a home in the Scottish Highlands, where they hope to enter semi-retirement and pursue new ventures. During the journey, the presenter comes face to face with the country's native wild cat.

programme.title: Holiday of My Lifetime with Len Goodman
programme.desc: Strictly Come Dancing's Len Goodman takes sports star Fatima Whitbread back to Burnham-on-Crouch in Essex to reminisce about a memorable holiday she had there in 1976. The pair travel to the caravan park where she and her family stayed, before her mum Maggie reveals the background to how she came to adopt Fatima. She also returns to the school field, where Len learns how to throw a javelin.

programme.title: Flog It!
programme.desc: Paul Martin and experts Anita Manning and Will Axon head to Wells Cathedral in Somerset where they uncover an intricate walking cane made from bone and some miniature paintings. The presenter also travels to Bristol to visit one of the country's oldest zoos.

programme.desc: Scotland international Duncan Weir, rugby union referee Nigel Owens, pundit Jonathan Davies and TV presenter and rugby enthusiast Nick Knowles join team captains Phil Tufnell and Matt Dawson for a special edition of the quiz. Presented by Sue Barker.

programme.title: EastEnders
programme.desc: The highs and lows of life with the residents of Albert Square, Walford.

programme.title: MasterChef
programme.desc: The four heat-winners enter the quarter-final, in which they face the Critic's Brief. Guest judge Tracey MacLeod provides a simple instruction for a main dish - the twist being, the amateur cooks don't know who has set it until they face the Independent's restaurant critic to hear her verdict. It's then back to the kitchen to prepare a dessert, again based on MacLeod's brief. This time, the one that doesn't make the grade fails to reach the knockout week.

programme.title: The Musketeers
programme.desc: After the Queen's run-in with Rochefort, he provides evidence of a letter she wrote to her brother, the King of Spain - as a result of which she is suspected of treason. Fearing for her safety, the Musketeers steal her away from the palace while searching for evidence that Rochefort is a Spanish spy. But it seems nobody is safe from the count's grasp, not even the King - with devastating consequences. Swashbuckling adventure, starring Howard Charles, Luke Pasqualino, Santiago Cabrera and Tom Burke, with Marc Warren and Alexandra Dowling.

programme.title: The Graham Norton Show
programme.desc: A compilation of highlights from the recent run of the chat show, which has featured the host in conversation with guests including Meryl Streep, Will Smith, David Beckham, Jennifer Aniston, Benedict Cumberbatch, One Direction and Judi Dench. Last in the series.

programme.title: Would I Lie to You?
programme.desc: Stand-ups Sarah Millican and Jon Richardson, actor David Harewood and comic Bob Mortimer join team captains David Mitchell and Lee Mack for the panel show, trying to hoodwink their opponents with absurd facts and plausible lies about themselves. Rob Brydon hosts.

programme.title: Saturday Kitchen Live
programme.desc: James Martin is joined by chefs and celebrity guests for the cookery show, which also features BBC archive highlights and wine choices for the dishes prepared in the studio.

programme.title: Football Focus
programme.desc: Dan Walker and guests look ahead to the weekend's fixtures, which include Liverpool v Manchester United and Hull City v Chelsea. Plus, team news ahead of the early kick-off between Manchester City and West Bromwich Albion.

programme.title: Live Six Nations Rugby Union
programme.desc: Italy v Wales (Kick-off 12.30pm). The final day of the championship gets under way with this clash at the Stadio Olimpico, as Wales look for a third away win of the tournament. Having lost their opener at home to England, Wales bounced back well with wins on the road in Edinburgh and Paris, and they will expect to round off their campaign with victory over the Azzurri, whom they have beaten in their last seven meetings. With analysis by Carlo del Fava, Shane Williams and Martyn Williams.

programme.title: Live Six Nations Rugby Union
programme.desc: Scotland v Ireland (Kick-off 2.30pm). Coverage of the second of today's three fixtures comes from Murrayfield, as the nations play their final match of the campaign, with the visitors aiming to win the title for the second successive year. Scotland entered the tournament with cautious optimism, but lost each of their first three fixtures, although all by seven points or less, and the defeat to Italy in their last home match was a huge blow to their aspirations, leaving them in danger of finishing bottom of the table. With analysis by Keith Wood and Andy Nicol.

programme.title: Live Six Nations Rugby Union
programme.desc: England v France (Kick-off 5.00pm). This year's championship reaches a climax at Twickenham, where the final standings will be decided. England have finished second in the standings for the last three years and there is every chance that they could do so once again following their defeat to Ireland in Dublin in their third fixture. Les Bleus have seldom provided a dynamic attacking threat this year, scoring just two tries in their first three matches as they struggle to find the right formula ahead of the World Cup, which gets under way in September and will be the next time these nations are involved in competitive action. With analysis by Clive Woodward and Thomas Castaignede.

programme.title: The Voice UK
programme.desc: Emma Willis and Marvin Humes present the first live round of the singing contest, in which the 12 remaining acts perform for a place in the semi-final. After all three acts in each team have performed, Tom Jones, Will.i.am, Rita Ora and Ricky Wilson will choose one to progress straight through to the next stage of the competition - leaving the remaining two on each team to go head to head in a public vote.

programme.title: The Voice UK
programme.desc: Emma Willis and Marvin Humes announce the result of the public vote to decide which four acts will be going home - leaving Tom Jones, Will.i.am, Rita Ora and Ricky Wilson with just two each for next week's semi-final.

programme.title: Match of the Day
programme.desc: Gary Lineker presents highlights of the latest Premier League clashes, including Newcastle United v Arsenal at St James' Park and Manchester City v West Bromwich Albion at the Etihad Stadium. The Gunners continued their quest for a top-four finish away to the mid-table Magpies, while City looked to maintain their slim chances of catching Chelsea at the top of the table, as they welcomed the Baggies. Plus, action from Aston Villa v Swansea City, Southampton v Burnley, Stoke City v Crystal Palace, Tottenham Hotspur v Leicester City and West Ham United v Sunderland. With analysis by Phil Neville and Alan Shearer.
